question: Question_04_(b)
sols:
To begin with, to get our bounds of integration and where the
intersection points are, we follow same steps as in
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH101/April_2013/Question_04_(a)}{part
(a)} to find that the curves intersect when
$\displaystyle x = \pi/2, \pi, 3\pi/2$. Further, the top function on
$\displaystyle [\pi/2,\pi]$ is $\displaystyle 4+\pi \sin x$, whereas the
top function on $\displaystyle [\pi,3\pi/2]$ is
$\displaystyle 4+2\pi-2x$.

Since we are revolving around the horizontal line
$\displaystyle y = -1$, the radius of the discs change for every value
of \emph{x}. Hence we will integrate over all \emph{x} values to get the
volume of revolution. To find the radius of the discs as a function of
\emph{x}, note that we need to add 1 to the function value since the
radius is given by

\[\displaystyle \text{radius = } \text{function} - \text{axis} = f(x)-(-1) = f(x)+1\]

where $\displaystyle f(x)$ is the function. The volume of revolution is
given by
$\displaystyle \pi \int_a^b (\text{outer radius}^2-\text{inner radius}^2) \ dx$,
so

\begin{align*}
V & = \pi\int_{\pi/2}^\pi [(4+\pi\sin x+1)^2-(4+2\pi-2x+1)^2] \ dx \\
& \qquad + \pi\int_{\pi}^{3\pi/2} [(4+2\pi-2x+1)^2-(4+\pi\sin x+1)^2] \ dx
\end{align*}
hints: Make sure you remember which direction the discs are going.

The volume is given by
$\displaystyle \pi \int_a^b (\text{outer radius}^2-\text{inner radius}^2) \ dx$

Remember to revolve around $\displaystyle y = -1$, not
$\displaystyle y = 0$. How does this affect the radius?
